root.pub-comments: This paper is primarily a study of the Hlai group; accordingly, the other subgroups of Kra-Dai are not elaborated in this tree. The author also notes, concerning the subgrouping of Kra-Dai: "Bearing in mind that this classification is still tentative and awaiting final proof, the figure below represents a more articulated working model of the Kra-Dai family" (Norquest 2007:15).

child.geography: The Hlai languages are spoken exclusively on the island of Hainan, China.
child.pub-comments: Language population of modern Hlai languages: 798,800 (Norquest 2007:17).

child.publications: Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.
Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.
Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.

child.pub-comments: Language population: 44,000 (Norquest 2007:17). "The Run group itself divided into Baisha and Yuanmen, due at least partly to contact with Tongzha, with which Yuanmen shares several areal innovations" (Norquest 2007:35).

child.publications: Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.
Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.
Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.
Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.

child.pub-comments: Language population: 62,500 (Norquest 2007:17). "The speakers of Cunhua and Nadouhua, which I consider to be essentially Hlai languages based on their core vocabulary, are considered to be Chinese by the government and are counted as such" (Norquest 2007:16).

child.geography: Spoken close to the northwestern coast in Dongfang.
child.publications: Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.
Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.
Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.
Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.

child.pub-comments: Language population: 178,000 (Norquest 2007:17). "It is difficult to subgroup the Qi group, as some evidence shows that Zandui groups with Tonzha, and other evidence shows that it groups with Baoting; for now, the Qi branch will be shown with a tripartite structure" (Norquest 2007:35).

child.geography: Spoken in great swaths throughout the western and southern parts of the island, penetrating north as far as many of the North Central Hlai languages, which form enclaves within them.
child.publications: Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.
Norquest, Peter K. 2007. A Phonological Reconstruction of Proto-Hlai.
